subject: Critical Thinking
courseTitle: Evidence & Truth: How We Know What's Real

topics.title: What Makes Something Evidence?

hook.text: A friend says they saw a ghost. Is that evidence? A camera shows nothing. Is that evidence? Both are â€” but of what?

buildup.text: Evidence is any observation that changes how likely a claim is to be true. It's not proof â€” it's a shift in probability.

discovery.text: Good evidence is relevant, reliable, and replicable.

twist.text: Absence of evidence IS evidence of absence â€” when you'd expect to find evidence if the claim were true.

climax.text: Evidence doesn't speak for itself. It must be interpreted â€” and interpretation is where bias enters.

punchline.text: Evidence shifts probability. It doesn't guarantee truth.

quiz.question: What is the role of evidence in reasoning?
options: It shifts the probability that a claim is true

topics.title: Anecdotes vs. Data: The Battle for Truth

hook.text: 'My grandma smoked till 97.' Cool story. The data says smoking kills 480,000 Americans per year.

buildup.text: Anecdotes are vivid, memorable, and emotionally compelling. Data is abstract, boring, and statistically reliable.

discovery.text: Our brains weight anecdotes more heavily because of the availability heuristic â€“ stories are easier to recall than.

twist.text: But data has limits too: averages hide variation, samples can be biased, and statistics can be cherry-picked.

climax.text: The best reasoning uses data for conclusions and anecdotes for illustration â€” never the reverse.

punchline.text: Stories move us. Data should steer us.

quiz.question: Why are anecdotes unreliable as evidence?
options: They represent individual cases, not systematic patterns

topics.title: The Burden of Proof: Who Must Prove What?

hook.text: 'Prove that invisible unicorns DON'T exist.' You can't â€” and you shouldn't have to. The burden is on the claimant.

buildup.text: The burden of proof rests on whoever makes the claim. Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.

discovery.text: Carl Sagan codified this: 'Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.' A claim's burden scales with its.

twist.text: Shifting the burden is a common trick: 'You can't prove it's NOT true, so it might be!' That's not how evidence works.

climax.text: In law, science, and philosophy, the default is non-belief until evidence is presented. The null hypothesis rules.

punchline.text: If you make the claim, you bring the evidence.

quiz.question: Who bears the burden of proof?
options: The person who doubts the claim

topics.title: Testimony and Trust: When to Believe Others

hook.text: You believe the Earth orbits the Sun. Have you verified it yourself? No. You trust scientists.

buildup.text: Testimony â€“ information from others â€“ is our primary knowledge source.

discovery.text: Reliable testimony comes from credible sources, corroborated accounts, and consistent track records.

twist.text: But expertise in one field doesn't transfer. A Nobel physicist's opinion on economics deserves no special weight.

climax.text: The key question: does this person have both the expertise AND the incentive alignment to tell the truth?

punchline.text: Trust isn't binary. It's calibrated to track record and incentives.

quiz.question: What makes testimony reliable?
options: Credibility, corroboration, and consistent track records

topics.title: Unfalsifiability: Claims That Can't Be Tested

hook.text: 'There's an invisible dragon in my garage.' You can't see it, detect it, or measure it. Is that a meaningful claim?

buildup.text: Karl Popper argued that a claim is scientific only if it can be falsified â€“ if there's a possible observation that.

discovery.text: Unfalsifiable claims are immune to evidence.

twist.text: Unfalsifiable doesn't mean false. It means the claim is outside the reach of evidence â€“ & therefore outside of science.

climax.text: Many pseudosciences protect themselves by becoming unfalsifiable.

punchline.text: If nothing could prove it wrong, nothing can prove it right either.

quiz.question: According to Popper, what makes a claim scientific?
options: It can potentially be falsified by evidence

topics.title: The Scientific Method: A Self-Correcting Machine

hook.text: Science isn't a collection of facts. It's a method for being wrong in productive ways until you're less wrong.

buildup.text: Observe, hypothesize, predict, test, revise. The cycle never ends because science doesn't claim final truth.

discovery.text: The key innovation: controlled experiments. Change one variable, hold others constant, measure the difference.

twist.text: Most scientific results are provisional â€“ 'best current explanation.' Newton's gravity was 'true' for 250 years until.

climax.text: Science's superpower isn't being right â€” it's being able to find and correct its own mistakes systematically.

punchline.text: Science doesn't prove. It disproves â€” and what survives is our best guess.

quiz.question: What is science's greatest strength as a method?
options: It systematically identifies and corrects its own mistakes

topics.title: Hypothesis vs. Theory vs. Law

hook.text: 'Evolution is just a theory!' This reveals a misunderstanding of what 'theory' means in science. It's not a guess.

buildup.text: Hypothesis: a testable prediction. Theory: a well-tested explanation supported by many experiments.

discovery.text: Theories don't 'graduate' into laws. They're different things. Gravity has both a law and a theory.

twist.text: In everyday language, 'theory' means guess. In science, it means the highest level of tested explanation.

climax.text: Germ theory, atomic theory, evolution â€“ these are as solid as science gets.

punchline.text: In science, 'theory' is a promotion, not a demotion.

quiz.question: What does 'theory' mean in science?
options: A well-tested explanation supported by extensive evidence

topics.title: Peer Review: Science Checking Its Own Homework

hook.text: A scientist claims a breakthrough. Before the world hears about it, other scientists tear it apart. That's peer review.

buildup.text: Peer review: independent experts evaluate a study's methods, data, and conclusions before publication.

discovery.text: It catches errors, biases, and overclaiming. Most submitted papers are rejected or require major revisions.

twist.text: Peer review is imperfect â€” reviewers have biases, prestigious authors get easier passes, and fraud can slip through.

climax.text: But it's the best system we have. Science without peer review is just someone's opinion with a lab coat.

punchline.text: Trust peer-reviewed science. But know the review system isn't perfect.

quiz.question: What is the primary purpose of peer review?
options: To have independent experts check methods, data, and conclusions
To decide who wins Nobel Prizes

topics.title: Replication Crisis: When Studies Don't Reproduce

hook.text: In 2015, scientists tried to replicate 100 psychology studies. Only 39% produced the same results. The crisis was born.

buildup.text: Replication is science's ultimate test: if others can't reproduce your results, maybe they weren't real.

discovery.text: Causes: p-hacking, publication bias, and small sample sizes.

twist.text: The crisis doesn't mean science is broken â€” it means science found its own flaws. That's the method working.

climax.text: Reforms are underway: pre-registration, larger samples, open data, and publishing negative results.

punchline.text: Science catches its own mistakes. That's not a crisis â€” it's a feature.

quiz.question: What caused the replication crisis in psychology?
options: P-hacking, publication bias, and small sample sizes

topics.title: Pseudoscience: What Science Isn't

hook.text: Astrology, homeopathy, & crystal healing all claim to be scientific.

buildup.text: Pseudoscience mimics the appearance of science â€” jargon, citations, lab coats â€” without the substance.

discovery.text: Red flags: unfalsifiable claims, reliance on anecdotes, conspiracy theories about suppression, & no peer-reviewed.

twist.text: The line isn't always clear. Some fields hover at the boundary â€” they may become science with better evidence.

climax.text: The demarcation problem (Popper): distinguishing science from pseudoscience is one of philosophy's hardest questions.

punchline.text: If it looks like science but can't be tested, it's wearing a costume.

quiz.question: What is the biggest red flag that something is pseudoscience?
options: Its claims cannot be tested or falsified

topics.title: Empiricism: Knowledge from Experience

hook.text: John Locke said the mind starts as a blank slate â€“ all knowledge comes from sensory experience.

buildup.text: Empiricism: the view that knowledge comes from observation and experience, not from innate ideas or pure reason.

discovery.text: It's the foundation of modern science. Don't theorize in a vacuum â€” go look, measure, test.

twist.text: But empiricism has limits. You can't observe mathematical truths, logical laws, or ethics.

climax.text: Hume's fork: meaningful statements are either empirical or analytic. Everything else is meaningless.

punchline.text: See it, test it, measure it. If you can't, ask why you believe it.

quiz.question: What is the core claim of empiricism?
options: Knowledge comes from observation and experience

topics.title: Rationalism: Knowledge from Reason Alone

hook.text: Descartes locked himself in a room with no experiments. Through pure reason alone, he tried to find certain knowledge.

buildup.text: Rationalism: the view that reason â€“ not experience â€“ is the primary source of knowledge.

discovery.text: 'Cogito, ergo sum' â€” I think, therefore I am. Descartes found one indubitable truth through reason alone.

twist.text: Mathematics is the rationalist's triumph: 2+2=4 needs no experiment.

climax.text: Modern philosophy combines both: empirical evidence for facts about the world, reason for logical & mathematical truths.

punchline.text: Some truths you see. Some truths you think. Both are real.

quiz.question: What did Descartes establish through pure reason?
options: That thinking proves his own existence (cogito ergo sum)

topics.title: Skepticism: The Art of Productive Doubt

hook.text: Pyrrhonian skeptics in ancient Greece suspended judgment on everything.

buildup.text: Philosophical skepticism: the position that certain knowledge may be impossible.

discovery.text: Healthy skepticism asks 'How do you know?' Unhealthy skepticism rejects everything and becomes conspiracy thinking.

twist.text: The key distinction: a skeptic doubts claims until evidence appears. A cynic rejects claims regardless of evidence.

climax.text: Scientific skepticism: open to new ideas, demanding of evidence, willing to change your mind.

punchline.text: Doubt isn't the enemy of knowledge. It's the engine.

quiz.question: What distinguishes healthy skepticism from cynicism?
options: Skeptics doubt until evidence appears; cynics reject regardless of evidence

topics.title: The Problem of Induction: Can the Past Predict the Future?

hook.text: The sun has risen every day for 4.5 billion years. Does that prove it will rise tomorrow? David Hume said no.

buildup.text: Induction: drawing general conclusions from specific observations.

discovery.text: Hume's problem: induction assumes the future will resemble the past. But that assumption itself relies on induction.

twist.text: Then black swans were discovered in Australia.

climax.text: Science depends on induction but can't justify it logically.

punchline.text: The past doesn't guarantee the future. We just bet on it.

quiz.question: What is Hume's problem of induction?
options: We can't logically justify that the future will resemble the past

topics.title: Paradigm Shifts: When the Whole Framework Changes

hook.text: For 1,400 years, Earth was the center of the universe. Then Copernicus moved the Sun to the center. Same sky, new truth.

buildup.text: Thomas Kuhn: science doesn't progress smoothly.

discovery.text: A paradigm is a framework of assumptions. Normal science works within it. Anomalies pile up until the framework breaks.

twist.text: During a shift, old and new paradigms are 'incommensurable' â€” they don't share enough assumptions to compare directly.

climax.text: Copernicus, Darwin, Einstein, plate tectonics â€“ each required scientists to abandon deep assumptions, not just add.

punchline.text: Sometimes progress means changing the question, not the answer.

quiz.question: What is a paradigm shift according to Thomas Kuhn?
options: A revolutionary change in the fundamental framework of scientific assumptions
A political change in science funding

topics.title: The Evidence Pyramid: Ranking Sources of Proof

hook.text: Not all evidence is equal. An anecdote, a case study, and a meta-analysis all count â€” but they don't count the same.

buildup.text: The evidence pyramid ranks reliability: expert opinion at the bottom, systematic reviews at the top.

discovery.text: Bottom to top: anecdote â†’ case study â†’ cohort study â†’ RCT â†’ systematic review â†’ meta-analysis.

twist.text: Higher on the pyramid isn't always better. A well-done cohort study can beat a poorly designed RCT.

climax.text: Quality matters more than type.

punchline.text: Better evidence exists. But even the best needs scrutiny.

quiz.question: What sits at the top of the evidence pyramid?

topics.title: Randomized Controlled Trials: The Gold Standard

hook.text: James Lind gave some sailors oranges & others vinegar in 1747. The orange group didn't get scurvy.

buildup.text: RCTs: randomly assign people to treatment or control groups, apply the intervention, measure the difference.

discovery.text: Randomization eliminates confounding variables â€” differences between groups are due to chance, not hidden factors.

twist.text: But RCTs can't test everything. You can't randomly assign people to 'smoking' or 'non-smoking' groups for 30 years.

climax.text: Double-blinding (neither participants nor researchers know who gets what) prevents placebo effects and researcher bias.

punchline.text: The best way to test a cause: change one thing, randomize everything else.

quiz.question: Why is randomization essential in clinical trials?
options: It eliminates confounding variables between groups

topics.title: Meta-Analysis: Combining Studies for Stronger Answers

hook.text: One study says coffee prevents cancer. Another says it causes cancer.

buildup.text: Meta-analysis: statistically combining results from multiple studies to find an overall effect size.

discovery.text: By pooling data, meta-analyses have more statistical power â€” they can detect small effects that individual studies miss.

twist.text: Garbage in, garbage out. A meta-analysis of poorly designed studies produces a precise but wrong answer.

climax.text: The Cochrane Collaboration produces the world's most trusted meta-analyses â€” the basis for evidence-based medicine.

punchline.text: One study is a hint. A meta-analysis is the closest thing to an answer.

quiz.question: What is a meta-analysis?
options: An analysis of the analysis method
A statistical combination of results from multiple studies
A review of a single study

topics.title: Observational Studies: When Experiments Are Impossible

hook.text: You can't randomly assign people to live near power lines for 20 years. So scientists observe and compare. It's messier.

buildup.text: Observational studies watch what happens naturally â€” no intervention. Types: cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional.

discovery.text: The smoking-cancer link was established through observational studies â€” an RCT would have been unethical.

twist.text: The flaw: confounding. People who eat organic food are also wealthier. Is the health benefit from food or money?

climax.text: Bradford Hill criteria help evaluate observational evidence: strength, consistency, temporality, dose-response.

punchline.text: When you can't experiment, observe carefully. Then check everything twice.

quiz.question: What is the main weakness of observational studies?

topics.title: Statistical Significance vs. Practical Significance

hook.text: A study finds that a drug reduces blood pressure by 0.5 mmHg. Statistically significant. Clinically meaningless.

buildup.text: Statistical significance means the result is unlikely due to chance. It says nothing about the size of the effect.

discovery.text: Practical significance asks: is the effect large enough to matter in the real world?

twist.text: With 10 million participants, even trivial differences become 'significant.' The p-value is a function of sample size.

climax.text: Always ask two questions: 'Is it statistically significant?' AND 'Is the effect large enough to matter?'

punchline.text: Significant doesn't mean important. Read the effect size.

quiz.question: What does statistical significance (p < 0.05) actually tell us?
options: The result is unlikely due to chance alone
The effect is large enough to matter

topics.title: Objective vs. Subjective Truth

hook.text: 'The Earth is 4.5 billion years old' & 'chocolate is the best flavor' are both called 'true.' They're not the same.

buildup.text: Objective truth: true regardless of what anyone thinks. Subjective truth: true for the individual's experience.

discovery.text: Science deals in objective truths (or approximations). Aesthetics, taste, and personal experience are subjective.

twist.text: The confusion: treating subjective truths as objective or dismissing objective truths as subjective.

climax.text: Both matter. But confusing which category a claim belongs to derails every conversation.

punchline.text: Your experience is real. That doesn't make it universal.

quiz.question: What distinguishes objective truth from subjective truth?
options: Objective truths hold regardless of individual perspective

topics.title: The Correspondence Theory: Truth Matches Reality

hook.text: 'Snow is white' is true if â€” and only if â€” snow is actually white. Truth is a match between statement and reality.

buildup.text: The correspondence theory: a statement is true when it corresponds to facts in the world. Aristotle's original position.

discovery.text: It's intuitive: 'The cat is on the mat' is true when there's a cat, a mat, and the cat is on it.

twist.text: Problem: how do we access 'reality' to compare it with our statements? We only have perceptions â€” which can be wrong.

climax.text: Rival theories exist: coherentism, pragmatism. The debate continues.

punchline.text: Truth matches reality. The hard part is checking the match.

quiz.question: What does the correspondence theory of truth claim?
options: Truth is what most people agree on
A statement is true when it corresponds to facts in reality
Truth depends on who says it

topics.title: The Limits of Human Knowledge

hook.text: There are questions we may never answer.

buildup.text: GÃ¶del proved that any sufficiently complex system contains true statements it can't prove. Math has built-in limits.

discovery.text: Heisenberg showed that measuring a particle's position destroys information about its momentum.

twist.text: The 'hard problem' of consciousness â€” why subjective experience exists at all â€” may be beyond the reach of science.

climax.text: Recognizing limits isn't defeatism. It's intellectual maturity â€” knowing what we can and can't know.

punchline.text: The deepest wisdom: knowing where knowledge ends.

quiz.question: What did GÃ¶del's incompleteness theorems prove?
options: Any sufficiently complex system contains true statements it can't prove

topics.title: Constructivism: Is Truth Built or Discovered?

hook.text: Is gravity 'out there' waiting to be discovered? Or is it a model humans built to make sense of observations?

discovery.text: Strong constructivism says all scientific 'truths' are social constructions â€” products of culture, not nature.

buildup.text: Constructivism: the view that knowledge is constructed by minds, not passively received from an objective reality.

twist.text: But airplanes fly. Vaccines work.

climax.text: Moderate constructivism: our descriptions are human constructions, but they're constrained by a real world that pushes.

punchline.text: We build the map. But the territory is real.

quiz.question: What does moderate constructivism claim about scientific knowledge?
options: Our descriptions are human constructions constrained by reality

topics.title: Evaluating Sources in the Information Age

hook.text: A blog post, a peer-reviewed paper, & a TikTok video all claim the same thing. Are they equally trustworthy?

buildup.text: CRAAP test: Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, Purpose. Five questions to evaluate any information source.

discovery.text: Who wrote it? What are their credentials? When was it published? What evidence supports it? Who funded it?

twist.text: Professional-looking websites can be completely false. Ugly forums can contain expert knowledge. Don't judge by design.

climax.text: The best habit: trace claims to their primary source. If a news article cites a study, read the study.

punchline.text: Don't trust the headline. Read the source behind it.

quiz.question: What does the CRAAP test evaluate?
options: Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, and Purpose of sources
The quality of a website's design

topics.title: Evidence-Based Thinking in Everyday Life

hook.text: You don't need a lab to think like a scientist.

buildup.text: Evidence-based thinking: making decisions based on the best available evidence rather than intuition, tradition, or.

discovery.text: It started in medicine (evidence-based medicine) and spread to education, policy, management, and personal decisions.

twist.text: It doesn't mean ignoring experience â€” it means combining experience with data and updating when new evidence appears.

climax.text: The daily habit: before accepting a claim, ask 'What's the source? How strong is the evidence?

punchline.text: Three questions a day keep bad reasoning away.

quiz.question: What is the core habit of evidence-based thinking?
options: Making decisions based on best available evidence, not just intuition

topics.title: The Map Is Not the Territory

hook.text: Alfred Korzybski said: 'The map is not the territory.' Your model of reality is not reality itself.

buildup.text: Every theory, model, & belief is a simplification of reality. Useful simplifications â€“ but simplifications nonetheless.

discovery.text: All maps distort. The Mercator projection makes Greenland look as big as Africa. Africa is 14 times larger.

twist.text: The danger: mistaking the model for reality. Economists treat markets as rational.

climax.text: George Box: 'All models are wrong, but some are useful.' Use models, but never worship them.

punchline.text: Your model works â€” until it doesn't. Stay ready to redraw the map.

quiz.question: What does 'the map is not the territory' mean?
options: Our models and theories are useful simplifications, not reality itself
We should only trust direct experience

topics.title: Intellectual Courage: Following Evidence Where It Leads

hook.text: Barry Marshall drank a petri dish of bacteria to prove ulcers were caused by infection, not stress. He was right.

buildup.text: Intellectual courage: following evidence to its conclusion, even when that conclusion is unpopular, uncomfortable, or.

discovery.text: Ignaz Semmelweis proved handwashing prevented deaths in 1847. Doctors rejected him. He died in an asylum. He was right.

twist.text: It's not just scientists. Everyday intellectual courage means changing your mind publicly when the evidence demands it.

climax.text: The hardest evidence to follow is evidence against your own identity.

punchline.text: The truth doesn't care about your comfort. Follow it anyway.

quiz.question: What is intellectual courage?
options: Following evidence to its conclusion even when it's uncomfortable

topics.title: The Limits of Empiricism

hook.text: David Hume woke up one morning and realized he couldn't prove the sun would rise.

buildup.text: Empiricism says all knowledge comes from experience. But experience only tells us what has happened, not what must.

discovery.text: The problem of induction: no amount of observed sunrises logically guarantees the next one.

twist.text: Science relies on induction daily â€” yet Hume showed it has no logical foundation. We trust patterns, not proofs.

climax.text: Karl Popper's solution: we can't prove theories true, only falsify them. Science advances by elimination.

punchline.text: Every sunrise is an act of faith in patterns.

quiz.question: What is the 'problem of induction' identified by Hume?
options: Past observations can't logically guarantee future outcomes

topics.title: Citizen Science and Crowdsourced Evidence

hook.text: Amateur birdwatchers discovered a New Zealand storm petrel thought extinct for 150 years.

buildup.text: Citizen science enlists ordinary people to collect data. Millions of observations create datasets no lab could match.

discovery.text: Projects like eBird & Galaxy Zoo produce real papers. Quantity of observers compensates for individual imprecision.

twist.text: But crowdsourced data has biases: people observe near roads, in daylight, in wealthy countries.

climax.text: Statistical corrections for observer bias turn messy crowd data into rigorous evidence.

punchline.text: A million amateurs can outperform one expert.

quiz.question: What is a key challenge of citizen science data?
options: It's always more accurate than professional data
Observer biases like location and timing skew results
